Words.Definition: adv. somewhat unwillingly

Words.Example Sentence: Our CEO renounced her position yesterday.
Words.Definition: v. to give up (usu. power or a position)

Words.Example Sentence: He renounced his friend after he caught her stealing money from him.
Words.Definition: v. to cast off

Words.Example Sentence: The mother reproached her daughter’s school for making students come in during a blizzard.
Words.Definition: v. to criticize

Words.Example Sentence: The father repudiated his son’s marriage.
Words.Definition: v. to refuse to recognize as true

Words.Example Sentence: She repudiated her son once she found out he’d married someone without telling her.
Words.Definition: v. to cast off

Words.Example Sentence: Water retention can make you weigh more on certain days.
Words.Definition: n. the act of keeping something

Words.Example Sentence: I felt satiated after eating a snack.
Words.Definition: adj. satisfied (usu. in hunger)

Words.Example Sentence: My brother is not very savvy when it comes to using public transportation.
Words.Definition: adj. having practical intelligence or knowledge

Words.Example Sentence: The scandalous politician decided it was best to resign from office.
Words.Definition: adj. morally offensive

Words.Example Sentence: It’s difficult for me not to scorn those who use improper grammar.
Words.Definition: v. to look down on with disdain

Words.Example Sentence: I am a scrupulous proofreader and never miss an error.
Words.Definition: adj. paying great attention to detail

Words.Example Sentence: The teacher scrutinized her students’ essays.
Words.Definition: v. to examine carefully and critically

Words.Example Sentence: Trees secrete a sticky substance called sap.
Words.Definition: v. to produce or release (a substance)

Words.Example Sentence: I am of the sentiment that you should never give out your passwords to anyone.
Words.Definition: n. opinion

Words.Example Sentence: Even though I’m not a big fan of porcelain dolls I appreciated the sentiment.
Words.Definition: n. a tender or moving gesture

Words.Example Sentence: The curtains on the window were so sheer you could clearly see inside the house.
Words.Definition: adj. so thin that light can shine through

Words.Example Sentence: This math problem is so simple even a first grader can solve it.
Words.Definition: adj. easy; not complex

Words.Example Sentence: The simple beauty of the ocean is what makes it memorable.
Words.Definition: adj. undecorated

Words.Example Sentence: Medieval peasants believed sinister demons could harm humans.
Words.Definition: adj. ominous

Words.Example Sentence: I stood in solidarity with other female students by refusing to wear the school’s sexist uniform.
Words.Definition: n. the joining of commonalities or common purposes among a group

Words.Example Sentence: Due to my condition I must eat salt sparingly.
Words.Definition: adv. insufficiently, meagerly, or in a restricted manner

Words.Example Sentence: Frogs typically spawn in ponds.
Words.Definition: v. to release eggs

Words.Example Sentence: The topic spawned an ongoing debate among his family members.
Words.Definition: v. to call forth or generate

Words.Example Sentence: Her bravery spurred others to act.
Words.Definition: v. to stimulate or incite

Words.Example Sentence: The squalid cabin needed a new roof and an exterminator.
Words.Definition: adj. run-down

Words.Example Sentence: Looking out at the stark landscape I felt a keen sense of isolation.
Words.Definition: adj. very plain; devoid of any details or features

Words.Example Sentence: The ball is static.
Words.Definition: adj. motionless

Words.Example Sentence: Her life has been static for the past three years.
Words.Definition: adj. changeless

Words.Example Sentence: The subordinate officers work every day.
Words.Definition: adj. lower in rank

Words.Example Sentence: My subordinate will check you in.
Words.Definition: n. someone lower in rank

Words.Example Sentence: You aren’t my boss—you can’t subordinate me to the role of receptionist!
Words.Definition: v. to make dependent on or put at a lower rank

Words.Example Sentence: I subsequently went home.
Words.Definition: adv. happening later or after something

Words.Example Sentence: I was shocked to find a substantial amount of money beneath the park bench.
Words.Definition: adj. very large in amount or degree

Words.Example Sentence: It is important for scientists to substantiate their theories whenever possible.
Words.Definition: v. to strengthen with new evidence or facts

Words.Example Sentence: I detected in her expression a subtle hint of irritation.
Words.Definition: adj. hard to detect or analyze

Words.Example Sentence: These boxes should be sufficient for our move.
Words.Definition: adj. enough; just meeting a requirement

Words.Example Sentence: The bartender was a surly fellow who wasn’t afraid to start a fight.
Words.Definition: adj. unfriendly; inclined to anger

Words.Example Sentence: They managed to surmount the language barrier by using a translation app.
Words.Definition: v. to get on top of or overcome

Words.Example Sentence: Children are more susceptible to certain illnesses than adults are.
Words.Definition: adj. to be vulnerable (to something)

Words.Example Sentence: Her tactful attitude toward our class made her one of my favorite teachers.
Words.Definition: adj. skilled at dealing with people

Words.Example Sentence: The rubberband was taut and ready to be fired.
Words.Definition: adj. pulled tight

Words.Example Sentence: Doorknobs are not as clean as they look and are often teeming with germs.
Words.Definition: adj. abundantly filled (usu. with living organisms)

Words.Example Sentence: She had a hostile temperament making her intimidating to most people.
Words.Definition: n. usual mood or feelings

Words.Example Sentence: We haven’t made any official arrangements yet but the tentative location for our wedding is Hawaii.
Words.Definition: adj. not yet finalized

Words.Example Sentence: Stained window glass isn’t as transparent as regular window glass is.
Words.Definition: adj. see-through; so thin that light can shine through

Words.Example Sentence: She was transparent about her plans to end her marriage.
Words.Definition: adj. truthful or easy to perceive

Words.Example Sentence: The journey was becoming treacherous but they continued on regardless.
Words.Definition: adj. dangerous and unstable

Words.Example Sentence: Tremendous news! You don’t have to repay your loans!
Words.Definition: adj. very large

Words.Example Sentence: Cell phones are ubiquitous these days.
Words.Definition: adj. being everywhere at once

Words.Example Sentence: Though the dress was cheap and unadorned it was by far her favorite one on the rack.
Words.Definition: adj. undecorated, plain

Words.Example Sentence: Parents should take care not to constantly undermine their children.
Words.Definition: v. to weaken or subvert (usu. gradually or secretly)

Words.Example Sentence: This sentence seems to underscore the overall meaning of the passage.
Words.Definition: v. to emphasize or give additional weight to

Words.Example Sentence: Belly dancers are known for their ability to skillfully undulate their stomachs.
Words.Definition: v. to move as ripples or in a wavy pattern

Words.Example Sentence: The unilateral decision was deemed unfair by the other party involved.
Words.Definition: adj. one-sided

Words.Example Sentence: The court’s decision is unjust—he should not go free.
Words.Definition: adj. unfair; not justified

Words.Example Sentence: My speech was an unmitigated disaster!
Words.Definition: adj. downright

Words.Example Sentence: The number of protestors was unprecedented.
Words.Definition: adj. completely new and never having happened before; historic

Words.Example Sentence: We plan to unveil our plans for the new company project on Sunday.
Words.Definition: v. to make visible; to reveal

Words.Example Sentence: He had the urge to tell his parents about his acceptance to Columbia but decided against it.
Words.Definition: n. desire or impulse

Words.Example Sentence: She urged her sister to apply to Stanford.
Words.Definition: v. to encourage or persuade

Words.Example Sentence: Your selfish actions do not validate your feelings for me.
Words.Definition: v. to prove or declare valid

Words.Example Sentence: The viability of the solution is questionable.
Words.Definition: n. ability to be done in a practical or useful way

Words.Example Sentence: It is vital that you respond by the deadline.
Words.Definition: adj. urgently necessary

Words.Example Sentence: My brother quickly broke his vow to never eat chocolate again.
Words.Definition: v. to promise

Words.Example Sentence: Wanting to look cool in front of your friends doesn’t warrant breaking the law.
Words.Definition: v. to prove to be reasonable

Words.Example Sentence: The farmer’s annual pumpkin yield exceeded 10000.
Words.Definition: n. production of an amount

Words.Example Sentence: Cars turning right on red must yield to oncoming traffic.
Words.Definition: v. to give way to or surrender to

Words.Example Sentence: Our experiment yielded many unique-looking vegetables.
Words.Definition: v. to produce or supply
